Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering National Engineering Laboratory for Green Productions of Alcohols-Ethers-Esters College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Xiamen University Xiamen 361005 China Graphical abstract In this study, we propose a simple strategy to prepare a noble-metal free catalyst, i.e., CeO2 supported on multi-wall carbon nanotube (CNTs). CNTs are treated by acid before the loading of CeO2, which is vital to the performance of catalysts. CeO2 on treated CNTs (CNTs-M) presents much higher TOC conversion and stability when compared with CeO2 on raw CNTs (CNTs-Raw). Kinetic study indicates that acid treatment greatly decreases the activation of the DMF oxidation. To investigate these phenomena, detailed characterizations are performed. We found that the acid treatment generated surface functional groups on CNTs which leads to the strong interaction between CNTs and CeO2. As a result, CeO2 on CNTs-M obtained better dispersion and higher amount of surface oxygen, which accounts for its superior performance. Keywords DMF Active oxygen Selective deposition CeO2 Carbon nanotubes 1 Introduction The rapid growth of populace and increasing number of chemical industries may generate hazardous and toxic organic compounds as by-products which are the key factors affecting the environment [1]. For instance, N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) is widely used in laboratories and factories due to its outstanding solubility. DMF and its derivatives commonly present as a pollutant in industrial wastewater [2,3], posing potential risks to environment and health [4–6]. Therefore, some wastewater treatment technologies have been developed, such as bio-treatment, physical separation, and chemical oxidation (wet oxidation, wet peroxide oxidation, and supercritical wet oxidation) [7–9]. However, these techniques are not feasible for growing industrial demand because of the high operating costs or low efficiency. Therefore, the development of a superior technology is required to meet the mentioned challenges. Recently, catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO) with the help of well-designed catalysts has attained significant scrutiny, as it provides a unique and highly efficient solution potent against industrial wastewater [10], which could directly oxidize the toxic pollutant into harmless products (CO2, N2, H2O). Besides, it uses undoubtable air, one of the cheapest and most convenient oxidants [11–13]. The benefits and efficiency of CWAO has been discussed quite thoroughly in our research group as well in others [8–10,14,15]. Noble metal-based catalysts have shown high efficiency in the removal of different forms of nitrogenous organic contaminants from wastewater. In a recent study, Fu et al. [16] found that 3%Pd based catalyst showed high stability and activity for DMF elimination. Sun et al. [17] depicted that the increase in surface area of ZrO2 supported catalyst could promote the DMF oxidation because of the enhanced metal dispersion. Nikolay et al. [18] applied several catalysts including Pt-Pd, Pt and Ru based catalysts to remove N-containing organic contaminants, among them Ru based catalyst showed better performance. Batygina et al. and Gong et al. [19,20] also reported the higher stability and activity of Ru based catalysts than that of Pt and Rh catalysts for the treatment of nitrogen-based organic substances. However, these catalysts are not recommended for the oxidation of DMF due to the extensive leaching of the active phase which is caused by the coordination with the lone-pair electrons in the intermediate compounds (e.g., amine) produced during the oxidation process [21]. Recently, our group has proposed a triple-layer structure to solve this problem [16]. Nevertheless, the high noble metal loading increases the catalyst synthesis cost, which is still a major challenge for its application. Cerium oxide, one of the most essential rare-earth metal oxides, is the most promising metal oxide with high oxygen storage capacity [22–24], which has been widely used in oxidation reactions [25,26] gas sensing [27], and photocatalysis [28]. Some recent studies show that the development of strong synergistic interaction between CeO2 and active metals can promote the activity in selective oxidation reaction [14,29–31]. Song et al. and Yu et al. [32,33] demonstrated that the presence of CeO2 could improve the dispersion of metal and provide oxygen thereby increasing the oxidation activity. Similar enhancement was also reported using CeOx-ZrOx in the CWAO of DMF [20]. However, the direct use of CeO2 as active sites for CWAO is rarely reported. With unique structure thermal stability and large specific surface area, multi-wall carbon nanotube (CNTs) are generally used to promote the dispersion of metals and metal oxides. Ni-Co supported on CNTs is considered as a highly efficient material for urea oxidation reaction (UOR) [34]. Rao et al., Fang et al. and Vijayakumar et al. [35–37] reported that CNTs improved the distortion and reducibility of CeO2 via strengthening the formation of active surface lattice oxygen. Liu et al. depicted that the addition of CeO2 increased the active surface area of CeO2-Pt/CNTs and CeO2/CNTs-Pt/CNTs thereby enhancing the methanol oxidation [38]. Peng et al. [39] performed DFT study and demonstrated that the electronic interactions between MnO2 and CNTs increased the activity of N-doped pristine CNTs. An important corollary of the above studies is metal oxides on the surface of CNTs prepared by different methods open a new window to noble metal free catalyst with low synthesis cost to fulfill the industries application. In this present study, we used pristine CNT (CNT-Raw) and treated/modified CNT (CNT-M) as support for CeO2. CeO2/CNT-Raw and CeO2/CNT-M were prepared using a simple two-step technique/wet chemistry method to enhance the metal support interaction. Their performance in the CWAO of DMF was examined by total organic carbon (TOC) instrument. The results showed that the modified CNTs with the inclusion of ceria performed significantly better than other prepared catalysts. Some reported results argue that the catalyst's activity is based on the amount of CeO2 [40,41]. However, this study discoveries that the total activity depends on the interaction between CeO2 and CNT, which directly affects the oxidizing ability of CeO2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Nitric acid (HNO3) (65–68 % pure), Xylene (C8H10), Phosphoric acid (H3PO4) were purchased from Sino-pharm-Chemical Reagent (SCR) Co. Ltd. (Shanghai China). CNTs used was prepared in our group. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Functionalization of CNTs CNTs were prepared in our group with outer diameter 28−38 nm [42]. Firstly, nanotubes were grinded well, and then treated with 68 % concentrated nitric acid (HNO3) at 100 °C for 5 h according to the mentioned method with a small modification to protect the CNTs structure [43]. After cooldown at room temperature under stirring, CNTs were washed with deionized water several times until pH of the solution reaches 7. Then, the obtained materials were dried at 100 °C for 12 h. 2.2.2 Preparation of CeO2/CNTs-M and CeO2/CNTs-Raw For the loading of CeO2 on the surface of the modified nanotubes, a combined two-step strategy was applied based on the previously reported methods with a small modification [44–46]. At first, xylene was used to fill in and protect the inner cavity of CNTs. The solution that contains both CNTs and xylene were sonicated for 1 h to ensure the xylene enters the CNT tunnel before introducing the Ce(NO3)3·6H2O. Then, 2.5 mL water and 0.538 g Cerium nitrate hexahydrate were mixed, and sonicated for 30 min. After that, it was added to the mixture that contains CNTs dropwise under stirring, followed by the sonification for 3 h. Eventually, the obtained material was dried at 100 °C for 12 h and then calcined in N2 for 1 h at 450 °C with 2 °C/min temperature ramp. The similar procedures were applied to make CeO2/CNTs-Raw using CNTs-Raw. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations The crystal phase measurements were performed using Rigaku X-ray diffractometer (XRD) with a filtered Cu-kα radiation at 40 kV and 30 mA with 2θ angular range between 10°-90°. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was obtained with PHI quantum 2000 scanning ESCA microprobe using monochromatic Al-kα radiation (1846.6 eV) as the X-ray source. The binding energy of spectra was calibrated using reference C 1s peak at 284.6 eV. Raman spectroscopy was obtained using confocal Raman microscope with an excitation of 532 nm laser light. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was performed on F-30-HRTEM (Netherland) using 200 kV voltage acceleration. Nitrogen adsorption desorption experiment was performed on micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument, and the specific surface area was calculated using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) were performed on micromeritics Autochem II 2920 instrument. The signal was detected using TCD detector. Furthermore, the real loading of CeO2 was investigated using thermogravimetric analysis (TG-209-F1 Germany) under the air flow rate 30 mL/min from atmospheric temperature to 960 °C. The loading of CeO2 was determined using the following equation: CeO2 (%) = (residual weight/weight loss) ×100 Rate of reaction and Arrhenius plot activation energy equation were used to determine the reason behind the high activity and stability. 2.4 Catalytic wet air oxidation of DMF Catalytic wet air oxidation of N, N-Dimethyl formamide (DMF) was carried out in a stainless-steel batch reactor with a total reactor volume of 100 mL. The system is capable of running batch experiments at pressure up to 15 MPa and temperature up to 250 °C. 15 mL solution with 2500 ppm DMF concentration and 0.1 g catalyst were fed in the reactor, and then the solution was purged with N2 at least three times to remove all the oxygen. After that, the reactor was heated to 180 °C with the stirring rate of 750 rpm. When the reaction temperature reached 175 °C, the reactor was filled with oxygen to maintain the partial pressure of 1.5 MPa during oxidation process. After 6 h, used catalyst was carefully collected, washed and dried at 100 °C for 12 h for further reaction. Total organic carbon (TOC) was measured by Shimadzu TOC-L analyzer. To avoid the effect of mass transfer, the effect of stirring rate was studied at the range of 200–1000 rpm. The reaction rate increased gradually from 200 to 700 rpm. Above 700 rpm, no difference of the rate was observed. For the measurement of initial reaction rate, the conversion was controlled below 10 %. The corresponding activation energy was obtained from the reactions performed at 140–180 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural investigation of hybrid (CeO2/CNTs) CNTs catalysts 3.1.1 XRD X-ray diffraction patterns of mentioned materials (CNTs-Raw, CNTs-M, CeO2, CeO2/CNTs-Raw, and CeO2/CNTs-M) are shown in Fig. 1 . For CNTs-Raw, five peaks are observed at 26.25°, 43.30°, 77.60°, 44.70° and 51.80°. The peaks around 44.70° and 51.80° represent the impurities/catalytic particles remaining in the synthesis process; after the treatment with acid, the catalyst particles/impurities peaks almost disappeared with no effect on the CNTs structure. The rest peaks (26.25°, 43.30°, 77.60°) match well with the CNTs, indicating that the graphitization structure of CNTs remained during the acid treatment [47,48]. The addition of CeO2 on the surface of modified and un-modified CNTs can be confirmed by the peaks, which are well-matched with the patterns of CeO2 [38]. The full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the peaks of CeO2/CNTs-Raw is higher than that of CeO2/CNTs-M, indicating that sizes of CeO2 on these two types of supports are different. This has also been confirmed by the TEM results. 3.1.2 SEM and High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) Scanning electron microscope (SEM) was also performed to investigate the microstructure of selected catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the SEM images for CNT-Raw and CNTs-M, which clearly demonstrates that structure of modified CNTs remained after treatment. HR-TEM was performed for CeO2/CNTs-Raw (Fig. 3 a-c) and CeO2/CNTs-M (Fig. 3d-f) to investigate the structural properties. The uniform distribution of CeO2 particles on the surface of CNTs-M is clearly shown in Fig. 3d-f, while CeO2 aggregates and forms big particles on CeO2/CNT-Raw (Fig. 3a-c). The deposition of ceria nanoparticles was strongly affected by the functional group of CNT. Aggregation of CeO2 in CeO2/CNTs-Raw probably results from the weak interaction between CeO2 and carbon surface. The corresponding activity may decrease because of the low amount of available active sites [49]. Fig. 3c shows the HR-TEM images of CeO2 in CeO2/CNTs-Raw. The observed inter planer space is 0.30 nm and 0.28 nm, which match with that of CeO2 [111] and CeO2 [200]. The dominant facets of CeO2/CNTs-M shown in Fig. 3f are CeO2 [111]. The size distribution of CeO2/CNTs-M and CeO2/CNTs-Raw can be found in Fig. 3g and h respectively. CeO2/CNT-M possesses narrow and uniform particle size distribution in the range between 1.8 nm and 4.38 nm (mean particle size 2.56 nm). The formation of large agglomerates (CeO2) on CNT-Raw was observed (Fig. 3a, b). The mean size of CeO2 is 18.0 nm. 3.1.3 BET Table 1 shows the BET surface area results of modified and unmodified samples. The surface area was calculated using the nitrogen adsorption isothermal method. CNTs-Raw and CeO2/CNTs-Raw exhibited a much lower surface area and pore volume than un-modified samples. This might result from the residual impurities generated during the synthesis process of CNTs-Raw, which could block the tubes thereby lowering the surface area of CNTs. The increase in surface area of CNTs-M was thought to be caused by the acid treatment [48], which removed the impurities and the metals (as catalyst for producing CNTs) on tubes. Furthermore, the addition of CeO2 on CNTs decreased the surface area of CNTs. This is caused by the entry of nanoparticles in the pores, leading to the reduction of volume. It is also a well-documented fact that the surface area of the material decreases with an increasing quantity of the active component until the impregnated component's monolayer coverage is completed [50,51]. 3.1.4 Thermogravimetric analysis Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using TG apparatus for selected catalysts to verify the real and theoretical loading of CeO2 and combustion stability. The theoretical loading of ceria is 30 % for both catalysts, while the values obtained from TGA (Fig. 4 ) for CeO2/CNTs-M and CeO2/CNTs-Raw are 30.9 % and 33.8 % respectively. The higher mass loss of modified CeO2/CNTs-M than that of CeO2/CNTs-Raw results from the presence of functional groups. By contrast, the lower temperature and higher rate of mass loss was also observed for CeO2/CNTs-M. It is well documented that CeO2 can promote the reaction between carbon and oxygen [35]. Thus, the interaction, a kind of “contact”, between CeO2 and CTNs in CeO2/CNTs-M is stronger than that of CeO2/CNT-Raw. However, carbon nanotubes show the opposite trend. The combustion temperature of CNTs-M (730 °C) is higher than that of CNTs-Raw (700 °C). The main reason is the catalytic effect of the impurities/catalyst particles in CNT-Raw, which promotes the combustion. The acid treatment removed the impurities/catalyst from CNTs, which has been confirmed by the previous results [52]. 3.1.5 Raman Raman technique was used to investigate the surface properties of these materials. The band around 1346−1356 cm−1, called d-band, is associated with the disordered carbon and defects in CNTs, while the band around 1580−1587 cm−1, called G-band, is assigned to the well-ordered carbon related to a splitting of the E2g stretching mode of graphite and reflects the structural intensity of the sp2-hybridized carbon atoms. The band around 1609 cm−1 is the overtone of d-band [53]. The intensity ratio between the d-band (ID) and the G-band (IG) is sensitive to the chemical processing and is an index of the defects of the CNTs [54]. Two prominent characteristic bands for the CNTs-Raw and modified CNTs-M (Fig. 5 a) were detected, which are the D band (1346 cm−1, 1357 cm−1) and G band (1581 cm−1, 1587 cm−1) respectively. The small increment in ID/IG ratio is caused by impurities removal, meaning nearly no fundamental structure change from CNTs-Raw to CNTs-M. The wavenumber of G mode in CNTs-M is 10 cm-1 higher than that of CNTs-Raw, which is related to the change of electrochemical structure, e.g., the increase of functional groups attached to CNTs-M walls/edges or/and the increased oxygen content in the nanotube's framework. After the loading of CeO2 on the surface of CNTs, both CeO2/CNTs-M and CeO2/CNTs-Raw present lower ID/IG ratio, which is 1.06 and 0.99 respectively. These significant changes in band ratio directly confirm the interaction between CeO2 and CNTs. It is noticed that when CeO2 is introduced to the CNTs-M and CNTs-Raw wall to form CeO2–CNTs composites, the bonding state of CNTs would change. On the other hand, the feature peak of Ce-O vibrational mode of ceria (459 cm−1 and 570−640 cm−1) is evident for CeO2/CNTs-Raw but vanished for CeO2/CNTs-M. The much lower intensity of these peaks is attributed to Ce-CNTs bonding, indicating the high dispersion of ceria nanoparticles [55]. 3.1.6 FT-IR The FT-IR spectra of CeO2/CNTs-M, CeO2/CNTs-Raw, CNTs-M, and CNTs-Raw are shown in Fig. 5b. The broad peak at 3200−3550 cm−1 is attributed to the hydroxyl group's stretching vibration (free/bonded). The band around 1570 cm−1 is attributed to the graphitic structure of sp2-hybridized carbon in CNTs, while the band at 1160 cm−1 is assigned to sp3 carbon [53,54]. New peaks at around 1640 cm−1 and 2900 cm−1 in CNTs-M are attributed to the CO stretching vibrations of COOH group and hydroxyl moieties at carbon surface. The intensity of the peak at 1400 cm−1 increases after treatment, indicating the addition of the OH group [44,56]. In summary, much more functional groups are connected on CNTs-M than on CNTs-Raw. After CeO2 loading, in the range of wavenumber 1500−1650 cm−1, 1384 cm−1, and 1000−1100 cm–1 for CeO2/CNTs-M, small increment in intensity was observed, while the intensity of the peaks around 1400 cm−1 and 1641 cm−1 decreases. These clearly indicate the interaction between CeO2 and carbon tube wall, which is consistent with the reported results [51,57]. The IR spectra also show one significant peak located at 505 cm−1 for CeO2/CNTs-M catalyst. It represents the Ce-O vibration of the CeO2 nanoparticles on the surface of CNTs-M [55]. 3.1.7 H2-TPR The reducibility of selected catalysts (CNTs-Raw, CNTs-M, CeO2/CNTs-Raw, and CeO2/CNTs-M) were evaluated by H2-TPR, and the profile is shown in Fig. 6 a. For CNTs-Raw, the first peak at lower temperature (350 °C) represents the reduction of impurities, and 2nd peak at around 590 °C describes the methanation at high temperature. For CNTs-M, the first peak at around 490 °C indicates the reduction of functional group, and 2nd peak is also the methanation. There are no other peaks observed at lower temperatures, because, after treatment, impurities are removed. For CeO2/CNT-Raw, the temperature of the impurity’s reduction decreases to 300 °C, which is well documented that ceria's addition promotes the reduction. The interaction between impurities and CeO2 would produce a new type of oxygen species that can be reduced by hydrogen at a lower temperature [58]. The peak at 370 °C results from the surface oxygen of deposited CeO2 on carbon, while the peak that represents the bulk oxygen of CeO2 is located at 585 °C and cannot be distinguished from the methanation. By contrast, impurities related peaks cannot be observed for CeO2/CNTs-M. The reduction of surface oxygen of CeO2 occurred at 370 °C, while the peaks that represent bulk oxygen are located at around 535 °C [36,59]. Besides, methanation is greatly inhibited. 3.1.8 O2-TPD The oxygen mobility in the materials was further studied using O2-TPD (Fig. 6b). The peaks of CNTs-Raw and CNTs-M represent the impurities and functional group on the CNTs surface respectively. For both CeO2/CNTs-Raw and CeO2/CNTs-M, three oxygen desorption peaks are observed. Yao and Chen et al. [59,60] already described these three types of oxygen (surface capping oxygen/active surface oxygen, surface lattice oxygen, and bulk lattice oxygen/sharing oxygen) available in ceria structure. The peak at around 120 °C is the surface capping oxygen, while the peak at 300−450 °C is the surface lattice oxygen. Prominent peak with high intensity and area at around 120 °C for CeO2/CNTs-M means that it has more exchangeable structure oxygen. This is consistent with the higher DMF oxidation activity of CeO2/CNTs-M when compared with CeO2/CNTs-Raw. Katsaounis et al. [61] mentioned that surface lattice oxygen (medium temperature peak) also plays an important role in an oxidation reaction [62]. The strong interaction between CNTs-M and CeO2 oxides leads to more lattice defects and oxygen vacancies and promotes the mobility and desorption of capping oxygen at a lower temperature [63]. Ceria decorated CNTs-M with high pore diameter and surface area desorbed more surface lattice oxygen, which also accounts for its high activity. 3.1.9 XPS XPS were applied to analyze the surface composition and chemical state of selected catalysts. The O 1s spectra of CeO2/CNTs-M and CeO2/CNTs-Raw catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 a. The O 1s spectra deconvoluted by curve fitting procedure. The peak at lower binding energy (528.7–530.5 eV) corresponds to the lattice oxygen O2− (donated as Oβ) and peak at 531.2–532.4 eV illustrates the surface capping oxygen such as O- (donated as Oα). For CeO2/CNTs-M and CeO2/CNT-Raw, both of them were observed. Another peak at 533.5 eV represents the water or functional group. [64,65]. The Oα/(Oα+Oβ) clearly show that surface-active oxygen (67 %) is much more available on the surface of CeO2/CNTs-M. The surface oxygen is much more important than other kind of oxygen in catalytic oxidation [36,46]. The C 1s spectra of CeO2/CNTs-M and CeO2/CNTs-Raw present two prominent peaks at 284.5 eV and 285.5 eV (Fig. 7b). The peak at 284.4 eV illustrates the CC component of CNTs, and the observed peak around 285.5 eV is attributed to the presence of CO component [66]. In addition, the peak at 288.5 eV was only observed for CeO2/CNTs-M, and it can be attributed to the (Ce-C-O) and interaction between ceria and carbon wall [51]. Fig. 7c shows the Ce 3d spectra of CeO2/CNTs-M and CeO2/CNTs-Raw. The peaks around 885.0 eV and 903.8 eV are assigned to Ce3+, and the rest of the peaks can be illustrated as Ce4+. The relative concentration of Ce3+, Ce4+ and surface oxygen (Oα ) are summarized in Table 2 . The relative concentration of Ce3+ is much higher in CeO2/CNTs-M (19.52 %) when compared with that of CeO2/CNTs-Raw (8.12 %). This is consistent with the available surface oxygen (Oα ) in CeO2/CNTs-M catalyst. Fig. 3e demonstrates the uniform dispersion of CeO2 on CNTs-M, which is related to the surface functional group. After acid treatment, the newly formed function group (e.g., −COOH) on CNT-M can be used as a nucleation site for CeO2 nanoparticle. The cation in the solution of cerium nitrate can interact with carboxyl group (−COOH) on the surface of nanotubes. [36,44]. On the other hand, the improved surface area of CNTs-M was thought to be caused by the acid treatment [48], which removed the impurities (metal particles/as catalyst for producing CNTs) in the confined space of the CNTs, resulting in the increase of the space between tubes and surface area. Both the metal/support interaction and improved surface area are responsible for the uniform dispersion of CeO2. 3.2 Catalytic wet air oxidation Reaction test 3.2.1 Catalytic reaction rate and activation energy The reaction rates of CeO2/CNTs-Raw and CeO2/CNTs-M were measured based on conversion versus reaction time at different temperatures, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 a. The strategy of CeO2 inclusion on the surface of CNTs can significantly affect the rate of reaction that occurs on the catalyst surface. For the same reactant on the surface of two different prepared catalysts, the obtained results are illustrated in Fig. 8a. The corresponding activation energy reaction rate and the obtained results are demonstrated in Fig. 8b. According to the obtained results at the same reaction conditions, catalysts prepared by modified CNTs, CeO2/CNTs-M exhibited much higher reaction rate than CeO2/CNT-Raw. At 180 °C, the reaction rate of CeO2/CNT-Raw is 1152.9 (mmol L−1 h−1), while the rate of CeO2/CNT-M reaches 2117.6 (mmol L−1 h−1). At lower temperatures, the reaction rate of CeO2/CNTs-M is around two times higher than that of CeO2/CNTs-Raw. The corresponding activation energy (donated as Ea) that can be obtained from the Arrhenius equation is shown in Fig. 8b. The calculated Ea of CeO2/CNTs-Raw and CeO2/CNTs-M are 120.32 ± 10.98 kJ/mole and 72.97 ± 5.09 kJ/mole respectively. 3.2.2 Catalytic stability and CeO2/CNTs leaching/deactivation test Recycling experiments were also performed to investigate the stability of CNTs-Raw, CNTs-M, CeO2, CeO2/CNTs-Raw, and CeO2/CNTs-M. After each reaction, catalyst was washed and dried at 100 °C for 12 h and then used for the next reaction. The results are shown in Fig. 9 . Of all the catalysts, CeO2/CNTs-M shows the best activity and stability. The conversion reaches 75 %, and no deactivation was observed for five consecutive reactions. The first-time reaction TOC conversion for CeO2/CNTs-Raw is 62.5 %. After the fifth reaction, the value drops to 59.5 %. CeO2 presents a similar trend with CeO2/CNT-Raw during the stability test, and its activity is between CeO2/CNTs-M and CeO2/CNTs-Raw. The CNT-Raw also shows stable TOC conversion (%), and its activity is higher than that of modified CNT at the first-time reaction. The possible reason is that the impurities (metals for producing CNTs) promote the oxidation of DMF. Nevertheless, the activity of modified CNTs increases gradually from the first to third reaction. This is probably attributed to the generation of more functional groups on the surface of CNTs-M. The deactivation of CeO2/CNTs-M and CeO2/CNTs-Raw was also studied. Results show that no deactivation of CeO2/CNTs-M was observed and TOC conversion could be maintained up to 75 %. The leaching of the catalysts was determined by ICP-OES using the 1 st and 5th reaction solution, and the results are shown in Table 3 . No leaching was detected for any of the tested reaction solution. Thus, the main reason for the deactivation of CeO2/CNT-Raw is thought to be the agglomeration of nano CeO2 (Fig. 3a, b). As is mentioned above, aggregation of CeO2 in CeO2/CNTs-Raw resulted from the weak interaction between CeO2 and CNTs surface because of lower amounts of functional groups. After several reactions, the CeO2 on CNT-Raw would move over the surface of CNT and form big particles, resulting in the low activity. This is consistent with the reported results of Fang et al. [36]. Based on the results of characterizations, we have got a basic understanding of the properties of tested materials. The acid treatment has a strong influence on the surface of CNTs by producing oxygen-containing groups. Impurities were also removed, but this has a minor effect on the catalytic performance. The generated oxygen-containing groups play an important role in the process of the CeO2 deposition, as they can interact with the CeO2 nanoparticles. The dispersion of CeO2 is greatly improved on modified CNT, and is much better than that of CeO2 on raw CNT. Based on the results of XRD, TEM and Raman shift, we have confirmed that the size of CeO2 on CNTs-M is lower than that of CeO2 on CNT-Raw. Nevertheless, the high activity of CeO2/CNTs-M is not only related to the number of exposed active sites. The much lower Ea of CeO2/CNTs-M indicates that the property of active cites is also modified. According to the results of XPS, TPR and TPD, the amount of surface capping oxygen and surface lattice oxygen on CeO2/CNT-M is larger. We tend to believe that the higher amount of surface oxygen over CeO2/CNTs-M accounts for its high activity. Besides, the strong interaction between CeO2 and modified CNT also helps stabilize the CeO2 nanoparticles as no deactivation was observed in five consecutive runs. 4 Conclusion CeO2 nanoparticles supported on the CNTs-M and CNTs-Raw were synthesized via a facile strategy and evaluated in the catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO) of DMF. Detailed characterizations were also performed to investigate the catalysts. These findings confirmed that the acid treatment generated surface functional groups on CNTs, which led to the enhanced interaction between CNTs and CeO2. This strong interaction not only improves the dispersion of CeO2 but also increases the surface oxygen in CeO2/CNTs-M. As a result, CeO2/CNTs-M shows much better catalytic activity and stability than CeO2/CNTs-Raw does. Kinetic results also confirmed that CeO2/CNTs-M had lower activation energy than CeO2/CNTs-Raw. All these experimental results suggest the potential application of CeO2-CNTs composite in catalytic wet air oxidation (CWAO) process. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we propose a simple strategy to prepare a noble-metal free catalyst, i.e., CeO2 supported on multi-wall carbon nanotube (CNTs). CNTs are treated by acid before the loading of CeO2, which is vital to the performance of catalysts. CeO2 on treated CNTs (CNTs-M) presents much higher TOC conversion and stability when compared with CeO2 on raw CNTs (CNTs-Raw). Kinetic study indicates that acid treatment greatly decreases the activation of the DMF oxidation. To investigate these phenomena, detailed characterizations are performed. We found that the acid treatment generated surface functional groups on CNTs which leads to the strong interaction between CNTs and CeO2. As a result, CeO2 on CNTs-M obtained better dispersion and higher amount of surface oxygen, which accounts for its superior performance.
coredata.dc:title: Noble metal free catalyst with High activity and stability for catalytic wet air oxidation of N, N-dimethylformamide
